bibl.title: H.W. Hull v Washing Territory. Recongizance of Crime
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

keywords.term: J.C. Nixon N.J. Black James Seavey James P Ludlow

div1.ab: Territory of Washington vs H.W. Hull
div1.p: Comes now this 14th day of November 1883 H.W. Hull and J.C. Nixon and N.J. Black well sure his and acknowledge and recongize themselves their heird executors and administrators bound into the Territory of Washington in the full sum of $500.

And the conditon of this recognizance is such that whereas the said defendant H.W. Hull has been tried and convicted by the Jury at the October time 1883 fo this Court of the crime of Keeping a house of ill fame.

And thereupon it was considered by the Court that the said defendant was guilty as charged in the Indictment, and the Judgement of the Court was that said defendant pay a fine of $300, and costs and that that he be imprisoned in the County Jail of King County, until such fine and costs are paid or until discharged
by law.
And whereas the said defendant has taken an appeal from said Judgement nad fine to the Supreme Court of this Territory.

Now therefore if the said H.W. Hull shall appear and attend at said Supreme Court at the next regular session in July A.D. 1884 to be held at Olympia W.T. from day to day and term to term thereafter. and abide by and perform all orders and Judgements of the said Court or until discharged according to law then this recongizance shall be void otherwise of full force and effect.
div1.ab: Territory of Washington County of King | ss.

I, James Seavey Clerk of the District Court of the Third Judicial District Washington Territory holding terms at Seattle in King County, for the counties of King and Kitsap; do hereby certify the foregoing to be a true, full and correct transcript of the Recoginzance taken in the above entitled cause now of need in my office.
(seal) Witness my hand and the Seal of the said Court at Seattle. this the 21st day of April A.D. 1884 James Seavey Ckerk. By James P Ludlow Deputy.
